title: Eric Mai
text:
Eric Mai







Policy Leader & Researcher
Housing & Community Development
I’m an experienced nonprofit leader with a background in history, urban planning, and community revitalization. For over five years, I have helped to increase knowledge and data accessibility around affordable housing, led growth and modernization at a policy and research nonprofit, and built relationships with non-traditional partners outside the housing industry.
I have a strong foundation in qualitative and quantitative data analysis and research design. More than anything, I believe in breaking down the barriers that prevent us from understanding complex topics by focusing heavily on data visualization, accessible language, and meeting people where they are.
I enjoy not just thinking about the work, but also how the work is done. Whether exploring ways to making work more efficient or creating systems that increase accountability and transparency, I believe that structure can lead to more flexibility and room for creativity.

title: About Me
text:
Touring with bands. Digging up history. Leading policy and developing affordable housing. The path to where I am now has been long and winding with lots of detours. But my diverse experiences have given me a unique perspective and skills to address any problem with passion and determination.





Growing up in Newport News, Virginia, I had early dreams of being a photographer for touring bands, documenting their lifestyle and going along for the ride. By taking risks, I was able to go on two national tours to see the United States.





While I had many opportunities to grow in the music industry, I felt a pull towards expanding my knowledge and professional opportunities. After a break from undergrad, I went back with a drive and passion for history. I finished my bachelor’s degree in art history after spending a month in the Middle East doing archaeology.





Upon graduation in 2012, I ended up at a cultural resources management firm doing archaeology across the Mid-Atlantic. Digging up layers of history throughout Virginia exposed me to Virginia’s expansive geography and culture. I was all in on archaeology at the time and decided to pursue a master’s degree in archaeology while working in the field.
















Previous


Next


My education in archaeology and heritage management exposed me to critical theory and a greater understanding of the contemporary impacts of control over historic narratives and resources. This increased consciousness illuminated the ways in which my employer was being unethical in our work.
I left the field of archaeology seeking to have a greater impact on existing communities and to bring a historic perspective to current development. Of all things, I decided to make a big pivot and go back to school to get another master’s degree.
In 2018, I went all in on urban planning at Virginia Commonwealth University. The program helped shape and develop my interest in housing and community development. After graduating in 2020 (during the pandemic), I landed a position with a consulting firm called HDAdvisors. For just over five years, I was exposed to Virginia’s affordable housing industry and helped to elevate zoning education, increase capacity among partners to solve their housing challenges, and brought innovative ideas to Virginia leaders.

title: Portfolio
text: Welcome to my portfolio! Here you’ll find a selection of my projects and work.

title: Portfolio
text:
Featured Projects

Virginia Zoning Atlas (2025)

Description: An interactive web map that compiles and analyzes local zoning ordinances in Virginia. Beginning as an independent web application focusing on the three major metropolitan regions of Virginia, the Virginia Zoning Atlas was later incorporated into the larger National Zoning Atlas project.
Technologies Used: R, Shiny, QGIS
Key Contributions:

Founded and led the development of the initial iteration of the Virginia Zoning Atlas
Secured over $5 million in grant funding to complete the full Virginia Zoning Atlas
Presented at multiple conferences and events in support of the atlas project

Links: Website



Middle Income Housing Programs: A National Scan (2025)

Description: Virginia Housing contracted with HousingForward Virginia to conduct a national scan of state-funded programs and initiatives serving households earning 80% to 120% area median income. This research provided Virginia Housing with valuable insights into state-level initiatives and high-production regions, informing future policy decisions and program implementations.
Key Contributions:

The first comprehensive national scan of state-level programs addressing middle-income housing needs
Identified 58 programs across 34 states, including three programs in Virginia
Programs ranged from homebuyer assistance, developer financing, and even public enterprises

Links: Report | Spreadsheet



Faith-Owned Property Ownership in Virginia (2024)

Description: The Virginia Center for Interfaith Public Policy commissioned Housing Forward Virginia to conduct a study quantifying the of land owned by faith-based organizations in Virginia. The report sought to support VICPP’s advocacy for Senate Bill 233, which aimed to grant religious organizations certain powers to overcome local zoning barriers for affordable housing development on their own land.
Technologies Used: R, QGIS
Key Contributions:

Determined that out of the over 4 million parcels in Virginia, 22,453 were identified as likely owned by a faith-based organization - equating to 74,116 acres
Identified a clear need for standardized parcel records and quality assurance among local government data collection
Identified zoning as a major barrier to housing development on a majority of faith-owned parcels in Northern Virginia

Links: Report | Presentation | APA Presentation



House Bill 854 Statewide Housing Study (2022)





Description: A report commissioned by the Virginia General Assembly to investigate housing needs across the Commonwealth and makes recommendations to state housing agencies, the General Assembly, and Governor’s Office for improving housing affordability and opportunity for all Virginians.
Technologies Used: Bookdown, Tableau
Key Contributions:

Investigated state-funded rental assistance program feasibility
Explored the overall affordable housing supply need in Virginia and across its various market regions
Evaluated the effectiveness of state-run affordable housing programs

Links: Report



HousingX 2022

Description: HousingX is an unconventional conference held by HousingForward Virginia that brings housing innovators within Virginia and across the nation together to explore new and emerging ideas to solve our housing crisis. The second HousingX conference was held in May 2022 in Newport News and brought over 200 individuals together.
Key Contributions:

Served as the main content planner, bringing Curtis Moody, FAIA, NOMAC (Moody Nolan), Anna Mackay (Sister City), Theo Henderson (We the UnHoused), and Zachary Mannheimer (Alquist 3D) as keynote speakers

Links: Website

title: Portfolio
text:
Other Projects

Connecting Housing and Health in the Potomac Health Foundation Service Area (2021): Study commissioned by Potomac Health Foundation to explore the interconnection between housing affordability and health outcomes in Prince William County, Stafford County, and Fairfax County. Report [PDF]
State of the Market and Local Policy: Accessory Dwelling Units in the Commonwealth of Virginia (2021): Findings of a data and information gathering exercise to provide the Accessory Dwelling Unit Stakeholder Advisory Group (SAG) and the Virginia Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD) input on key issues related to accessory dwelling units (ADUs) in the Commonwealth of Virginia. The work performed in this analysis and the SAG was implemented pursuant to House Bill 2053. Report [PDF]
George Washington Region Commission: Housing Affordability Study and Action Plan (2020): Study commissioned by the George Washington Regional Commission to study housing affordability in the Fredericksburg, VA region and provide policy recommendations to address housing challenges. Report [PDF]

title: Portfolio
text:
Data Visualizations

Virginia Zoning Atlas
The initial iteration of the Virginia Zoning Atlas was built in partnership with Kyle Walker and utilizes the R programming language and Shiny to deliver a fast and responsive web map.




Virginia Housing Choice Voucher Dashboard
This data dashboard was created to support the Virginia Housing Alliance and their advocacy for the 5,000 Families Pilot Program, a state-funded rental housing assistance program to support low-income households with school-aged children.




ADU Playbook
With increased attention on accessory dwelling units (ADU), this data dashboard and exploration was conducted to understand the range of ADU ordinances across Virginia. This compilation was a point-in-time analysis of how local governments regulate and restrict ADUs.



For more projects, visit my GitHub profile
